questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presented with inability to close the eyelid on the right side, deviation of angle of mouth towards Left side. She was diagnosed as having facial palsy. Stapedial reflex was performed. The stapedial reflex will be absent on which side in this patient?
questions.solution:
Patient is shown to be having inability to close an eyelid on the right side. Deviation of angle of mouth to the left side, which shows that patient has developed right sided facial palsy.

The afferent of the stapedial reflex is 8th nerve and the efferent is the 7th nerve.

It is a bilateral reflex hence the presence of stapedial reflex implies that there is no lesion in afferent, Central interconnection or efferent pathway.

In 8th nerve palsy stapedial reflex is absent on both sides (ipsilateral and contralateral),whereas in 7th nerve palsy stapedial reflex is absent only on side of lesion (ipsilateral side ). (Options B & C)

Key Takeaway:

In 8th nerve palsy stapedial reflex is absent on both sides (ipsilateral and contralateral), whereas in 7th nerve palsy stapedial reflex is absent only on side of lesion (ipsilateral side ).

Image reference: Andy cottom website.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with a complaint of decreased hearing in the left ear. His audiogram is given below. What would have been the turning fork test findings in his left ear?
questions.solution:
The red line in the given audiogram is depicting right ear. Findings in right ear appear normal.

The blue line in the audiogram is depicting left ear. The blue line shows increased air and bone conduction threshold.

There is no air-bone gap. This shows sensorineural hearing loss in left ear.

The Rinne test is positive in normal ear and in sensorineural hearing loss. Here in this case rinne will be positive in both ears. So Option A Or C is Possible.

The weber test is lateralized towards normal ear in sensorineural hearing loss.

Thus, in this case the weber is lateralized towards right ear. Hence, option A is the correct answer.

Key Takeaway:

Rinne's test: Positive: Normal ear or SNHL Vs Negative: CHL or Severe SNHL (False Negative)

Weber Localization: Remembered as SOCS - SNHL Opposite side and CHL Same Side.

Image reference: Research gate.

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument shown in the picture given below?
questions.solution:
A Siegel's pneumatic speculum has an eye piece which has a magnification of 2.5 times. It is a convex lens.

The eye piece is connected to aural speculum. A bulb with a rubber tube is provided to insufflate air via the aural speculum.

The advantages of this aural speculum is that it provides a magnified view of the ear drum.

The pressure of the external canal can be varied by pressing the bulb thereby the mobility of ear drum can be tested.

Since it provides adequate suction effect, it can be used to suck out middle ear secretions in patients with CSOM.

Ear drops can be applied into the middle ear by using this speculum.

Ear is first filled with ear drops and a snugly fitting Siegel's speculum is applied to the external canal.

Pressure in the external canal is varied by pressing and releasing the rubber bulb, this displaces the ear drops into the middle ear cavity.

Key Takeaway:

Siegel Speculum consists of an eyepiece which is connected to the aural speculum. A bulb with a rubber tube is provided to insufflate air via the aural speculum.

Image reference: www.docplexus.com.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presented with complain of vertigo decreased hearing and tinnitus since 2 months. Electro cochleography was advised in this patient. Picture is given below. Which of the following statements about the test is not true?
questions.solution:
The test given above is known as Electro cochleography (ECOG).

It is an objective test in which we record the electrical activity of the cochlea and auditory nerve. Here the electrode is passed through the tympanic membrane and placed on promontory. (Option A & B)

Three parameters are recorded in this test:

  1. Cochlear microphonics: This is the electrical activity from the hair cells. (Option D)
  2. Summation potential: This is the sum of all the electrical activity in the cochlea.
  3. Action potential: This is the electrical activity in the distal part of auditory nerve.

Normally, the ratio of SP/AP is less than 0.45 or 45%. In cochlear disease like Meniere's disease the ratio becomes more than 0.45 or 45%. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

In Diseases of cochlea like Meniere's summating Potential is Generated but Action Potential is not Generated. So SP / AP Ratio Becomes > 45%.

Image reference: ResearchGate journal.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child presented with the complaint of not responding to any auditory stimulation. Hearing assessment of the child was done using a test. The picture of the test is given below. Which of the following is true about this test?
questions.solution:
The test which is shown in this picture is called as Brainstem evoked response audiometry(BERA).

BERA is an objective test. It detects spontaneous electrical activity in the entire auditory pathway.

In a normal person, a 5 to 7 wave graph is formed out of which wave 5 is the most important one.

Uses:

  1. It is the best audiometry test to confirm hearing loss in infants. OAE is the best screening test thus OAE is used for screening and BERA is used for confirmation. (Option D)
  2. it is the best test to differentiate cochlear and retro cochlear hearing loss. (Option A & B)
  3. it is the best test for detecting nonorganic hearing loss (malingering). (Option C)
  4. it is the best test for acoustic neuroma and central auditory disorders.

Key Takeaway:

BERA is an Objective test that detects electrical activity of the entire auditory pathway in 5-7 different waves; so useful in differentiating snhl into cochlear vs Retrocochlear.

Cochlear - Delayed Wave 1

Retrocochlear - Normal Wave 1 but other waves absent / Reduced.

Image reference: EN1 neuro website.

In Acoustic neuroma, patients develop unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. It is of retro cochlear type. All the options given above are true for retro cochlear hearing loss except Tone decay <30 dB. Tone decay is >30 db seen in retro cochlear hearing loss.

Key Takeaway:

Retrocochlear pathology characterised by Tone decay > 30dB, Acoustic Reflex decay, Poor SISI Score, Absent Recruitment and decreased BERA waves 2-7.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with complain of dizziness. It gets aggravated on loud noise and on blowing of nose. He also complains that he could hear his own footsteps in the ear. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Superior semicircular canal dehiscence is a rare condition where bone between middle cranial fossa and superior semicircular canal is thin or missing. This can be congenital or acquired.

It leads to formation of 3rd mobile window in the inner ear facing the middle cranial fossa.

Any loud noise or pressure in the EAC or Valsalva or changes in intracranial pressure can stimulate the labyrinth, leading to vertigo.

The bone conduction threshold is decreased leading to increased sensitivity to bone conduction. Patient will be able to hear his own footsteps, his own voice.

Diagnosis is by HRCT temporal bone. Management includes surgical repair and avoidance of provoking stimuli.

Key Takeaway:

SCC Dehiscence:

  • Congenital / Acquired.
  • Hennebert's sign and Tullio phenomenon: +ve.
  • increased bone conduction: Able to hear own eye movements, footsteps heard louder, autophony & CHL.
  • Ix - HRCT

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with the complain of vertigo since 1 month. On examination, nystagmus was found and was torsional, has fixed direction, and it disappears with visual fixation. An another test is performed, it's picture is given below. Which of the following statement is not true for the test?
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is Bithermal caloric test.

This test is also known as Fitzgerald hallpike test.This test uses cold 30°C and warm 44°C water.

This procedure is done in the following order: Right warm-left warm-right cold-left cold. An interval of 8 min is given. Between each irrigation. (Option A)

Here the patient lies in supine position with head raised 30 degree forwards to make lateral SCC maximally responsive.

The normal response is cold water creates nystagmus to opposite side and warm water on the same side mnemonic COWS. (Option B)

This test stimulates Lateral SCC. (Option D)

Key Takeaway:

Bithermal Caloric test: on stimulating lateral SCC

  • With Cold water Opposite Side nystagmus
  • & Warm water Same side Nystagmus occurs.

questions.text: Fistula test was performed in a patient with complain of vertigo. The test was found to be positive but on further examination it was found that there is no evidence of middle ear disease (False positive). In which of the following condition it can be seen?
questions.solution:
Fistula test: in this test pressure changes are done in EAC by pressing and releasing the tragus alternatively.

If these pressure changes leads to development of vertigo than it is called positive fistula test. It can be seen in Lateral semi-circular canal fistula, post stapes surgery.

If the fistula test is negative in spite of fistula in the middle ear than it is called false negative fistula test. It can be seen in Cholesteatoma, if inner ear is dead. (Option C & D)

If the fistula test is positive but there is no evidence of disease in middle ear it is called false positive fistulatest.

It is also called Hannebert's sign. It is seen in congenital Syphilis where stapes is Hyper mobile, Meniere disease, superior semicircular canal dehiscence. (Option A)

Key Takeaway:

Fistula test:

  • False Positive - Congenital Syphilis, Meniere's disease, SCC Dehiscence
  • False Negative - Cholesteatoma, Dead Inner ear.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came with complaint of vertigo since 7 days. An examination was performed in which the patient was asked to keep looking at the examiner's finger while her head was moved briskly and abruptly. It was found that her eyes were lagging behind and there were saccades of eye at end of head movement. What is this suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Based on the description given above the test performed in the patient is called The Head - impulse test.

The head impulse test examines the patency of Vestibulo ocular reflex. The VOR helps in stabilizing the gaze on the object during different head movement, so that the image keeps falling over the fovea of the retina. (Option B & C)

The patient is asked to keep looking at an object while his head is moved briskly and abruptly. In normal patient or in Head impulse negative patient, the eyes moves in the opposite direction at the same speed as the head movement and will remain fixed on the target.

In absence of VOR or in Head impulse positive test the eyes will lag behind and there will be jerky catch up movement called saccades at the end to catch up the target.

Key takeaway:

Head impulse positive test implies the eyes will lag behind and there will be jerky catch up movement called saccades at the end to catch up the target in absence of Vestibulo Ocular Reflex.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presented with complaints of vertigo, tinnitus since 1 year. Her hearing was normal. The features shown above are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Normal hearing is seen only in vestibular neuritis out of the conditions given above.

Vestibular neuronitis is characterized by acute onset vertigo, associated with nausea and vomiting lasting for days to weeks.

This, as the name, is most likely because of viral infection involving the vestibular nerve.

The cochlear part is not involved, so the hearing remains normal. The caloric test shows diminished response.

It is a self limiting condition, the acute phase is managed by labyrinthine sedatives. Full recovery occurs within 6 to 12 weeks.

Options B & C: Acoustic neuroma and Meniere disease present with sensorineural hearing loss.

Key takeaway:

Vestibular Neuronitis:

  • Acute onset Vertigo & Normal hearing with Nausea Vomiting over days to weeks
  • Due to Viral Infection
  • Managed with Labyrinthine sedatives.
